title: The potential of this data package
text: manuscript presents open data product {TTS2016R}. Open data products result turning source data (open otherwise) accessible information adds value original inputs (see Arribas-Bel et al. 2021). product presented paper R data package currently consists three objects sourced 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) curated facilitate use analysis TTS data. package includes person--jobs origin-destinations, traffic analysis zone (TAZ) boundaries, planning/municipality boundaries Greater Golden Horse area (GGH) located southern Ontario, Canada (Data Management Group 2018). addition, package includes TAZ centroid--centroid travel times car computed using package {r5r} (Pereira et al. 2021). aim paper walk readers empirical home-based work commute data set, illustrate calculation impedance function, showcase can used calculate accessibility employment, invite use applications. Data TTS principle available public fully open, raw data can technically demanding, cumbersome work , requires multiple software process. pre-processing data R environment, {TTS2016R} offers slice TTS data useful understand patterns commuting work region. also provides open infrastructure additional TTS complimentary data sets amended authors wider open-source community future.

title: The potential of this data package
text: {TTS2016R} includes counts fully-employed population place residence counts full-time jobs place work aggregated TAZ (n=3,764 within survey boundaries). Unique identifiers use GTA06 Zoning System TTS. number jobs (3,081,900) workers (3,446,957) organized form origin-destination table, indicative patterns home--work commute (3,446,957 potential interactions). data retrieved Transportation Tomorrow Survey Data Retrieval System October 28, 2021 reflect potential interaction full-time employed people jobs within GGH survey boundaries shown Figure  defined 2016 TTS methodology (Data Management Group 2018). Also included {TTS2016R} travel times cost travel origin destination car; travel times calculated using R package {r5r}. travel times useful estimate cost travel calculate impedance functions, among possible uses. important note simplicity, interactions within {TTS2016R} assumed taken car, travel time calculated origin TAZ centroid destination TAZ centroid. centroid snapped nearest street line r5r travel time calculated trips assuming car travel mode. Additionally, travel times less equal 180 mins (3 hrs) calculated; threshold represents 99% trip’s travel times summarized descriptive statistics Table . TTS 2016 study area within Greater Golden Horseshoe Ontario, Canada.
code: #forming a complete descriptive statistic table  Statistics <- data.frame("Statistics" = c("Min.", "1st Qu.", "Median", "Mean", "3rd Qu.", "Max.", "NA's"))  Trips <- data.frame("OD_Trips" = c(summary(od$Persons)[[1]] %>% round(),                                     summary(od$Persons)[[2]] %>% round(),                                      summary(od$Persons)[[3]] %>% round(),                                     summary(od$Persons)[[4]] %>% round(),                                     summary(od$Persons)[[5]] %>% round(),                                    summary(od$Persons)[[6]]%>% round(),                                    NA))  Travel_time <- data.frame("OD_Travel_time" = c(summary(od$travel_time)[[1]] %>% round(),                                                 summary(od$travel_time)[[2]] %>% round(),                                                  summary(od$travel_time)[[3]] %>% round(),                                                 summary(od$travel_time)[[4]] %>% round(),                                                 summary(od$travel_time)[[5]] %>% round(),                                                 summary(od$travel_time)[[6]] %>% round(),                                                  3507))   TAZ_Area <- data.frame("TAZ_Area" = c(summary(ggh_taz$AREA)[[1]] %>% round(),                                        summary(ggh_taz$AREA)[[2]] %>% round(),                                        summary(ggh_taz$AREA)[[3]] %>% round(),                                        summary(ggh_taz$AREA)[[4]] %>% round(),                                        summary(ggh_taz$AREA)[[5]] %>% round(),                                        summary(ggh_taz$AREA)[[6]] %>% round(),                                        NA))  Workers <- data.frame("Workers" = c(summary(ggh_taz$workers)[[1]] %>% round(),                                      summary(ggh_taz$workers)[[2]] %>% round(),                                      summary(ggh_taz$workers)[[3]] %>% round(),                                      summary(ggh_taz$workers)[[4]] %>% round(),                                      summary(ggh_taz$workers)[[5]] %>% round(),                                      summary(ggh_taz$workers)[[6]] %>% round(),                                      NA))  Jobs <- data.frame("Jobs" = c(summary(ggh_taz$jobs)[[1]] %>% round(),                                summary(ggh_taz$jobs)[[2]] %>% round(),                                summary(ggh_taz$jobs)[[3]] %>% round(),                                summary(ggh_taz$jobs)[[4]] %>% round(),                                summary(ggh_taz$jobs)[[5]] %>% round(),                                summary(ggh_taz$jobs)[[6]] %>% round(),                                NA))   desc_stats <- cbind(Statistics, Trips, Travel_time, TAZ_Area, Workers, Jobs)  #kable tabling  desc_stats %>%   kable(format = "latex",         align="lrrrrrr",         booktabs = T,         col.names = c(" ", "(#)", "(min)", "(km^2)", "(#)", "(#)"),         caption = "\\label{tab:TTS-16-desc-stats}Descriptive statistics of the Persons, workers, and jobs for the traffic analysis zones (TAZ) from the TTS 2016 dataset along with estimated car origin-destination travel times.") %>%   add_header_above(c(" ", "Trips", "Car Travel Time", "Area", "Workers", "Jobs"), align = "r")%>%   kable_styling(full_width = "T",                  latex_options = c("scale_down"),                 position = "center")

title: The potential of this data package
text: origin-destination information consists cross-tabulation people employed full-time place residence (origin) places employment GGH (destination) using GTA06 zoning system. number workers jobs equal; boundaries survey permeable, workers reside within boundaries travel outside boundaries counted workers within origin TAZ, jobs TAZ filled workers reside outside GGH boundaries unknown since surveyed. mismatch results total number workers 1.12 times larger number jobs (.e., 3,446,957 workers 3,081,900 jobs). 2016 TTS survey boundaries drawn minimize difference opportunities destination supply origins still equal . said, data offer perspective potential home-based trips places employment , number trips taken equal number workers GGH. Number workers (top) jobs (bottom) TAZ GGH area specified 2016 TTS. cumulative distribution number jobs workers per TAZ 2016 TTS data set. Light blue shaded ranges correspond cumulative proabilities number workers per TAZ larger jobs per TAZ. Figure  presents number workers jobs per TAZ. can observed spatial distribution jobs workers unequal, indicative jobs-housing imbalance, can impact accessibility region (Levine 1998). Workers concentrated TAZ within center GGH along south-east northern boarder GGH. center GGH corresponds Greater Toronto Area (GTA) densely populated area southern Ontario (Statistics Canada 2022). south east border GGH neighbours Lake Ontario delineated urban built boundary Ontario Growth Plan home highest density working population GGH (Ontario 2019; Auditor General Ontario 2021). northern GGH border corresponds Simcoe, Dufferin, Kawartha Lake, Peterborough regions home lower density worker population density population (Auditor General Ontario 2021). Conversely, spread jobs GGH lower number workers indicating population spatially dispersed jobs. can also seen bottom plot Figure  high medium-low concentrations jobs often present areas workers scale transformed. words, though higher number TAZ workers zones jobs (.e., 791 TAZ workers : 396 TAZ jobs) mean workers per TAZ higher mean jobs (.e., 916 workers : 819 jobs) number TAZ extreme number jobs highest lowest percentiles significantly higher number workers; see following cumulative probability distribution Figure  94th 100th percentile 0th 34th percentile jobs TAZ higher number workers TAZ. means ranges, TAZ higher number workers jobs, echoing even spatial distribution workers observed Figure .
code: tts_workers <- tm_shape(ggh_taz) +   tm_fill(col = "workers", title = "Full-time employed people", palette = "-Spectral", style = "jenks") +   tm_compass(type = "arrow", position = c("left", "top"), size = 2) +   tm_scale_bar(breaks = c(0, 30, 60), text.size = 0.5, position = c("left", "bottom")) +   tm_layout(legend.position = c("right", "bottom"))  tts_jobs <- tm_shape(ggh_taz) +   tm_fill(col = "jobs", title = "Full-time jobs", palette = "-Spectral", style = "jenks") +   tm_compass(type = "arrow", position = c("left", "top"), size = 2) +   tm_scale_bar(breaks = c(0, 30, 60), text.size = 0.5, position = c("left", "bottom")) +   tm_layout(legend.position = c("right", "bottom"))  tmap_arrange(tts_workers, tts_jobs) Number <- rbind(ggh_taz$jobs %>% data.frame(),                  ggh_taz$workers %>% data.frame()) Group <- rbind(rep("Jobs", each=length(ggh_taz$jobs)) %>% data.frame(),                 rep("Workers", each=length(ggh_taz$workers))%>% data.frame())  ecdf_data <- cbind(Number, Group) colnames(ecdf_data) <- c("Number", "Group")  rect1 <- data.frame(xmin=115, xmax=3055, ymin=-Inf, ymax=Inf)    ggplot(ecdf_data , aes(x=Number, col=Group)) +    # geom_segment(aes(x = 115, y = 0, xend = 115, yend = 0.34), col = "blue", linetype=2) +   # geom_segment(aes(x = 3055, y = 0, xend = 3055, yend = 0.94), col = "blue", linetype=2) +   geom_rect(data = rect1, aes(xmin=xmin, xmax=xmax, ymin=ymin, ymax=ymax), fill="lightblue", alpha=0.2, inherit.aes = FALSE) +   stat_ecdf() +    scale_x_continuous(trans='sqrt', breaks=c(115, 3055, 10000, 20000, 30000, 40000)) +    scale_y_continuous(breaks=c(0, 0.25,0.34, .50, .75,0.94, 1.00)) +   labs(x = "Opportunities per TAZ",        y = "Cumulative probability") +        scale_color_manual("Opportunities",                           values = c("Jobs" = "Black",                                     "Workers" = "Red"))+   scale_linetype_manual("Opportunities",values=c(0,1)) +   geom_point(aes(x = 115, y = 0.34), col = "blue")+   geom_point(aes(x=3055, y=0.94), col = "blue") +   theme_minimal() +   theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5),         legend.position = c(0.90,0.75),         axis.line = element_line(colour = "black"),         panel.border = element_blank())

title: The potential of this data package
text: {TTS2016R} also includes travel time data home--work trip displayed Figure . travel time corresponds car commute calculated using R package {r5r} interpreted travel time work commute full-time employed people GGH. travel times calculated assuming following input parameters: maximum travel time less equal 180 mins (3 hrs) street network retrieved OpenStreetMaps GGH area. 3 hr threshold selected captures 99% trip taken (see travel times summarized Table ). important note travel times within data set calculated assuming car travel one departure time origins. assumptions completely realistic since know small proportion trips taken non-car modes travel time departures varies, however, possible data retrieval system obtain higher order tabulations allow us split data . Thus know trips made non-car modes exact departure times tables. Though modal split travel times can estimated methods (e.g., Allen Farber 2021; Higgins et al. 2021), simplicity, assume trips taken one-time departure car trip. Estimated total worker travel time (top) average worker travel time (bottom) TAZ GGH. can observed Figure , total travel time (min) resembles spatial trend distribution number employed people previous plot (Figure ). However, average travel time per trip TAZ presented, spatial distribution distinct plots presented far. can see areas around south-eastern border make Greater Toronto Hamilton Area (GTHA) (e.g., Hamilton, Halton, Peel, Toronto, York, Durham) Niagara Waterloo, average travel times moderately low. areas, travel times higher. Interestingly, even eastern areas (e.g., Peterborough) high employment high job concentration, average travel time higher within GTHA.
code: # remove all NA trips from dataset and set all 0min travel times to 0.1 min od  <- TTS2016R::od %>%    filter( !is.na(travel_time)) %>%    mutate(travel_time = ifelse(travel_time == 0, 0.1, travel_time))  all_tt <- od  %>%    dplyr::select(Persons, travel_time)  all_tt <- all_tt[rep(seq_len(dim(all_tt)[1]), all_tt$Persons), 2] #fitting impedance function gamma_ <- fitdistrplus::fitdist(data=all_tt, "gamma", method="mle", optim.method="Nelder-Mead") # transfer calibrated impedance function values to OD matrix od <- od %>%   mutate(f = dgamma(travel_time, gamma_$estimate["shape"], gamma_$estimate["rate"]))  #add the number of jobs and workers to the od matrix od_ft <- od %>% merge(ggh_taz %>% dplyr::select(GTA06, workers) %>% st_drop_geometry(),                    by.x = "Origin", by.y="GTA06", all.x = TRUE)  od_ft <- od_ft %>% merge(ggh_taz %>% dplyr::select(GTA06, jobs) %>% st_drop_geometry(),                    by.x = "Destination", by.y="GTA06", all.x = TRUE)   #calculate accessibility for workers from any origin to jobs in Toronto  GGH_c_accessibility <- od_ft %>%    mutate(GGH_A_ij = f * jobs) %>%   group_by(Origin) %>%   summarise(GGH_A_i = sum(GGH_A_ij, na.rm = T),             GGH_sum_tt_i = sum(travel_time),             GGH_tt_trips_i = mean(travel_time),             GGH_sum_f_i = sum(f),             GGH_f_trips_i = mean(f))  #Merge TO accessibly calculation to the ggh_taz: GGH_taz_acc <- ggh_taz %>% merge(GGH_c_accessibility, by.x=c("GTA06"), by.y=c("Origin"), all.x=T) tts_total_tt <- tm_shape(GGH_taz_acc) +   tm_fill(col = "GGH_sum_tt_i", title = "Total travel time\n per TAZ (min)", palette = "-Spectral", style = "jenks") +   tm_compass(type = "arrow", position = c("left", "top"), size = 2) +   tm_scale_bar(breaks = c(0, 30, 60), text.size = 0.5, position = c("left", "bottom")) +   tm_layout(legend.position = c("right", "bottom"))  tts_tt_per_trip <- tm_shape(GGH_taz_acc) +   tm_fill(col = "GGH_tt_trips_i", title = "Avg. travel time\n per TAZ (min)", palette = "-Spectral", style = "jenks") +   tm_compass(type = "arrow", position = c("left", "top"), size = 2) +   tm_scale_bar(breaks = c(0, 30, 60), text.size = 0.5, position = c("left", "bottom")) +   tm_layout(legend.position = c("right", "bottom"))  tmap_arrange(tts_total_tt, tts_tt_per_trip)

title: The potential of this data package
text: Impedance functions useful understand mobility behavior part, instance, gravity models spatial interaction (Wilson 1971; Haynes Fotheringham 1985) accessibility analysis many applications (Hansen 1959; Levinson 1998; Talen Anselin 1998; Reggiani, Bucci, Russo 2011; Páez et al. 2013; Kuai Zhao 2017; Barboza et al. 2021). origin destination matrix cost matrix (.e., travel times) can used combination estimate impedance functions. impedance function \(f(\cdot)\) depends cost travel locations \(\) \(j\) \(c_{ij}\); usually monotonically decreasing function, although sometimes function can increase reflect patterns separation activities; instance, separation land uses means short commuting trips relatively rare. can sometimes also fluctuations due hierarchical patterns, travelers bypass opportunities favor distant destinations offer economies agglomeration. useful technique calibrate impedance function use trip length distribution (TLD) measured origin-destination data (Horbachov Svichynskyi 2018; Batista, Leclercq, Geroliminis 2019). TLD representation likelihood proportion trips taken specific travel cost. data set, assume cost travel time, impedance function maps low travel times higher proportions trips, high travel times mapped low proportion trips. GGH data presented, empirical TLD (.e., proportion trips taken vs. travel time minutes) fitted density distribution using maximum likelihood techniques Nelder-Mead method direct optimization available within fitdistrplus package (Delignette-Muller Dutang 2015). Based goodness--fit criteria diagnostics seen Figure  Figure , gamma distribution selected presented data. Empirical TTS 2016 home-based car trip length distribution (black) calibrated gamma distribution impedance function (red) associated Q-Q P-P plots resulting calibrated impedance function given following general form estimated ‘shape’ \(\alpha\) = 0.831, estimated ‘rate’ \(\beta\) = 0.044 , \(\Gamma(\alpha)\) defined Equation (). \[\begin{equation} \label{gamma-dist} \begin{array}{l}\  f(x, \alpha, \beta) = \frac {x^{\alpha-1}e^{-\frac{x}{\beta}}}{ \beta^{\alpha}\Gamma(\alpha)} \quad \text{} 0 \leq x \leq \infty\\ \Gamma(\alpha) =  \int_{0}^{\infty} x^{\alpha-1}e^{-x} \,dx\\ \end{array} \end{equation}\] Cullen frey graphy 2016 TTS calculated travel times.
code: knitr::include_graphics("images/impedance_function.png") # remove all NA Persons from dataset and set all 0min travel times to 0.1min od  <- od %>% filter( !is.na(travel_time)) %>% mutate(travel_time = ifelse(travel_time == 0, 0.1, travel_time)) all_tt <- od  %>% dplyr::select(Persons, travel_time) all_tt <- all_tt[rep(seq_len(dim(all_tt)[1]), all_tt$Persons), 2] fitdistrplus::descdist(data=all_tt) #> summary statistics #> ------ #> min:  0.1   max:  179  #> median:  17  #> mean:  19.09844  #> estimated sd:  15.31425  #> estimated skewness:  1.482847  #> estimated kurtosis:  7.343217

title: The potential of this data package
text: noted , impedance functions essential component accessibility analysis. Equation () shows accessibility \(A_i\) weighted sum opportunities can reached location \(\), given cost travel \(c_{ij}\). Summing opportunities neighborhood \(\) defined impedance function \(f(\cdot)\), provides estimates number opportunities can reached \(\) certain cost. \[\begin{equation} \label{eq:conventional-accessibility} A_i = \sum_{j=1}^JO_jf(c_{ij}) \end{equation}\] : \(\) accessibility. \(\) set origin locations. \(j\) set destination locations. \(O_j\) number opportunities location \(j\). opportunities activity add sort supply area; \(c_{ij}\) measure cost moving \(\) \(j\) \(f(\cdot)\) impedance function \(c_{ij}\). Accessibility (top) normalized accessibility (bottom) employment GGH area Accessibility property origin (.e., origin TAZ data), landscape opportunities (.e., TAZ destinations data), transportation infrastructure (.e., travel time table). Figure  presents accessibility estimates result impedance function calibrated preceding section. top plot, raw accessibility values, presents distinct radial trend majority TAZ around Toronto high accessibility values values gradually decrease TAZ Toronto’s boundary. Alternatively, bottom plot Figure  present worker-normalized accessibility values. words, accessibility value TAZ divided number workers TAZ. patterns plot similar Greater Toronto Area radial trend observed top plot less extreme (.e., smaller spread).
code: GGH_taz_acc <- GGH_taz_acc %>%   mutate(avg_A_per_W = GGH_A_i/workers) ## accessibility access_TTS_GGH <- tm_shape(GGH_taz_acc) +   tm_fill(col = "GGH_A_i", title = "Accessibility \n(A_i)", palette = "-Spectral", style = "jenks") +   tm_compass(type = "arrow", position = c("left", "top"), size = 2) +   tm_scale_bar(breaks = c(0, 30, 60), text.size = 0.5, position = c("left", "bottom")) +   tm_layout(legend.position = c("right", "bottom"))  access_normalized_TTS_GGH <- tm_shape(GGH_taz_acc) +   tm_fill(col = "avg_A_per_W", title = "Average accessibility \nper worker", palette = "-Spectral", style = "jenks") +   tm_compass(type = "arrow", position = c("left", "top"), size = 2) +   tm_scale_bar(breaks = c(0, 30, 60), text.size = 0.5, position = c("left", "bottom")) +   tm_layout(legend.position = c("right", "bottom"))  tmap_arrange(access_TTS_GGH, access_normalized_TTS_GGH)

title: An augmented 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) data package: worker and place of employment counts, trips and estimated travel time to work in the Greater Golden Horsehoe area, Canada
text: package contains objects sourced 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) curated facilitate use analysis TTS data. TTS 2016 one largest travel surveys southern Ontario, Canada, slice survey cleaned, packaged, augmented easy use R environment.

title: An augmented 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) data package: worker and place of employment counts, trips and estimated travel time to work in the Greater Golden Horsehoe area, Canada
text: Installation:
code: if (!require("remotes", character.only = TRUE)) {       install.packages("remotes")   } remotes::install_github("soukhova/TTS2016R",                         build_vignettes = TRUE)

title: An augmented 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) data package: worker and place of employment counts, trips and estimated travel time to work in the Greater Golden Horsehoe area, Canada
text: 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) data Greater Golden Horseshoe (GGH) area province Ontario, Canada (43.6°N 79.73°W) included; specifically location origins destinations defined Traffic Analysis Zones (TAZ), associated municipality boundaries, number jobs workers origin destination, trips (primary mode) origin destination morning home--work commute. Also included calculated travel times car (calculated via r5r) derived impedance function values corresponding cost travel based trip length distribution.  See plot spatial visualization number workers jobs within TAZ:  See .Rmd files \data-raw folder additional details included data sets compiled. See vignettes detailed examples using data sets comparing comparison different accessibility measures.

title: An augmented 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) data package: worker and place of employment counts, trips and estimated travel time to work in the Greater Golden Horsehoe area, Canada
text: purpose data package make data TTS 2016 easily freely available analysis R environment. Currently, data package provides slices TTS 2016, invite others community request additional data, report issues, even contribute data package. interested contributing, please try adhere following steps: notice spelling errors hick-ups, please submit issue. use data package like share interesting use case analysis, please fork repository, save analysis file vignettes submit pull request. Analysis files reviewed added added articles (full credit).

what: TTS2016R: An augmented 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) data package: worker and place of employment counts, trips and estimated travel time to work in the Greater Golden Horsehoe area, Canada — TTS2016R-package
title: TTS2016R: An augmented 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) data package: worker and place of employment counts, trips and estimated travel time to work in the Greater Golden Horsehoe area, Canada — TTS2016R-package
text: package includes count workers (origin), count places employment (destination), count associated trip (primary modes) origin destination, estimated car travel times origins destinations (using package `r5r`). data retireved 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey [TTS](http://dmg.utoronto.ca/transportation-tomorrow-survey/tts-introduction), travel survey Greater Golden Horse area (GGH) located southern Ontario, Canada. packages associated spatial boundaries faciliate analysis including: traffic analysis zone (TAZ) boundaries (retrieved TTS 2016), planning boundaries associated muncipalities (retrieved TTS 2016), census metropolitan areas (CMA) census aggloomeration (CA) boundaries retrieved Canadian Census. data package consists objects sourced 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) curated facilitate use analysis TTS data. package includes worker--jobs origin -destinations traffic analysis zone (TAZ) boundaries Greater Golden Horse area (GGH) located southern Ontario, Canada. package also includes associated spatial boundary files.

title: TTS2016R: An augmented 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) data package: worker and place of employment counts, trips and estimated travel time to work in the Greater Golden Horsehoe area, Canada — TTS2016R-package
text: https://github.com/soukhova/TTS2016R

title: TTS2016R: An augmented 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) data package: worker and place of employment counts, trips and estimated travel time to work in the Greater Golden Horsehoe area, Canada — TTS2016R-package

title: census metropolitan area (CMA)/census agglomeration (CA) boundaries in the Greater Golden Horseshoe (GGH) area and associated data. — ggh_cma
census metropolitan area (CMA)/census agglomeration (CA) boundaries in the Greater Golden Horseshoe (GGH) area and associated data. — ggh_cma
text: simple feature class (sf) polygon object containing 16 rows 4 variables; row represents unique census metropolitan area (CMA) census agglomeration (CA) associated geo-referenced geometry. CMA CA consist one adjacent municipalities around core. CMA/CA boundaries defined purpose Canadian Census based population. , core CMA must population least 50,000 entire CMA must population least 100,000. CA smaller population, thir course must population least 10,000. CMAUID unique identifier census metropolitan area (CMA)/census agglomeration (CA). CMANAME name census metropolitan area (CMA)/census agglomeration (CA). CMATYPE one character field indicating whether unit census metropolitan area, tracted census agglomeration non-tracted census agglomeration. "B" CMA "D" CA census tracts, "K" CA census tracts. geometry sfc polygon geometry (boundaries).

title: census metropolitan area (CMA)/census agglomeration (CA) boundaries in the Greater Golden Horseshoe (GGH) area and associated data. — ggh_cma

Planning boundaries in the Greater Golden Horseshoe (GGH) area and associated data. — ggh_pd
text: simple feature class (sf) polygon object containing 105 rows 5 variables; row represents unique planning region associated geo-referenced geometry. MUN name municipality /planning boundary. PD unique ID. REGION unique ID corresponding greater region PD part . REGION_name Names regions corresponding REGION ID. geometry sfc polygon geometry (boundaries).

title: Traffic analysis zones boundaries in the Greater Golden Horseshoe (GGH) area and associated data. — ggh_taz
Traffic analysis zones boundaries in the Greater Golden Horseshoe (GGH) area and associated data. — ggh_taz
text: simple feature class (sf) polygon object containing 3764 rows 10 variables; row represents unique TAZ associated features. GTA06 Unique ID traffic analysis zone (TAZ). AREA Area TAZ units km^2. REGION Retrieved ggh_pd object. unique ID corresponding greater region planning district (PD) part filtering analysis, PD, simplified. CMAUID Retrieved ggh_cma object. unique identifier census metropolitan area (CMA)/census agglomeration (CA). Within, filtering analysis can easily linked census data, simplified. workers number full-time workers TAZ. jobs number full-time workers declare typical place employment TAZ. LTGO_split percentage full-time work related trips made origin destination using local transit /GO transit (regional transit) primary mode. W_split percentage full-time work related trips made origin destination using bicyle primary mode. BC_split percentage full-time work related trips made origin destination walking primary mode. geometry sfc polygon geometry (boundaries) TAZ.

title: Traffic analysis zones boundaries in the Greater Golden Horseshoe (GGH) area and associated data. — ggh_taz
text: "2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey" Data Management Group accessed November 14 2021.

what: An origin and destination table of workers, place of employment, trip counts, and estimated travel times. — od
title: An origin and destination table of workers, place of employment, trip counts, and estimated travel times. — od
text: object contains trips made origin (TAZ) destination (TAZ) full-time workers work destinations; sourced 2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) Greater Golden Horseshoe (GGH) area. Also contained within calculated car travel time trip calculated using TAZ centroids r5r October 2021.

title: An origin and destination table of workers, place of employment, trip counts, and estimated travel times. — od
An origin and destination table of workers, place of employment, trip counts, and estimated travel times. — od
text: dataframe containing 103076 rows 17 variables; row represents unique trip origin TAZ destination TAZ associated features. Origin unique ID origin traffic analysis zone (TAZ). equivalent IDs used 'GTA06'. Destination unique ID destination traffic analysis zone (TAZ). equivalent IDs used 'GTA06'. Persons number full-time workers origin work destination. T_LT number work-related trips taken origin destination local transit excluding GO transit (regional transit service) primary mode. T_LTGO number work-related trips taken origin destination local transit GO transit (regional transit service) primary mode. T_GO number work-related trips taken origin destination GO transit (regional transit service primary mode. BC number work-related trips taken origin destination bicyle (primary mode). W number work-related trips taken origin destination walking (primary mode). C_DPC number work-related trips taken origin destination driver private car (primary mode). C_PPC number work-related trips taken origin destination passenger private car (primary mode). C_TA number work-related trips taken origin destination taxi (primary mode). C_RS number work-related trips taken origin destination paid ride-share  (primary mode). C_SB number work-related trips taken origin destination school bus (primary mode). M number work-related trips taken origin destination motorcycle (primary mode). O number work-related trips taken origin destination another mode (primary mode). sum_trips total number work-related trips taken origin destination modes. travel_time car travel time origin destination assuming 7:00 departure TAZ centroids Oct. 20 2021.

title: An origin and destination table of workers, place of employment, trip counts, and estimated travel times. — od
text: "2016 Transportation Tomorrow Survey" Data Management Group accessed November 14 2021. Travel times calculated using r5r
